section.name: Welcome to Mod4j
section.p: Mod4j is a project that focuses on Model Driven Software Development. It's goal is to improve the productivity of Java software development by using Domain Specific Languages.

li.a: What are the features of Mod4j?
Where do I get help with Mod4j?

ol.li:
Make sure you've installed Java JDK version 5 (1.5_10 or greater). You can download one from the
Sun download site
.

Download
and install Eclipse with modeling plug-ins. To minimize time spending on version en dependency conflicts we already have a version waiting for you to download. This version based on Eclipse Europa 3.3.2, OAW 4.2 (Xtext 4.3.0), EMF 2.3.1 and has some convenient plug-ins (like Subclipse). You can download a Windows or Linux archive from our project share
here

Make sure you start Eclipse with de right options, e.g on a linux system: /path-to-eclipse-mod4j/Eclipse-europa/eclipse -vm /path-to-jdk1.5.0_15/jre/bin/java -vmargs -Xms512m -Xmx512m -XX:PermSize=512m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m

Make sure the text file encoding in Eclipse is set to 'UTF-8'. You can verify and set this in the field 'Text file encoding' by navigating to 'Window -> Preferences... -> General -> Workspace'. For Linux users UTF-8 is usually the platform encoding, and no change will be necessary.

subsection.name: Generating the DSL-editors
subsection.p: While the metamodel and its associated syntax is still under heavy development, you should be prepared to generate the model editors yourself from the metamodel and the syntax definitions, before you can start modelling:

ol.li:
Check out the source code of the mod4j project from the Subversion URL
https://viewsvn.smart-java.nl/wsvn/mod4j/trunk
into a directory. See the link Project information for information on how to do this.
Import the module modules/BusinessDomain/BusinessDomain.mm as Existing Projects into Workspace into Eclipse, in a new workspace.

Right-click on BusinessDomainDsl in the editor pane, and choose Generate All from the context-menu. You will see three projects appear in the Package Explorer: BusinessDomain.mm.edit, BusinessDomain.mm.editor and BusinessDomain.mm.tests.
In all these modules, create a new folder src-gen.

Right-click the file
BusinessDomain.xtext/src/genXtextEditor.oaw,
and choose Run As -> oAW Workflow from the context-menu.
Right-click the module BusinessDomain.xtext.editor and choose Run As -> Eclipse Application from the context menu.
In the new Eclipse session: import the modules BusinessDomain.mm, BusinessDomain.generator and the needed BusinessDomain.example.* modules.

Now you should be able to run one of the genrator workflow's in the BusinessDomain.example.* modules.
Right-click the file BusinessDomain.example.*/src/workflow.oaw and choose run as
Run As -> oAW Workflow from the context-menu.
